Title: Highly linked tournaments
Abstract: © 2015 Elsevier Inc.A (possibly directed) graph is k-linked if for any two disjoint sets of vertices {x1, . . ., xk} and {y1, . . ., yk} there are vertex disjoint paths P1, . . ., Pk such that Pi goes from xi to yi. A theorem of Bollobás and Thomason says that every 22k-connected (undirected) graph is k-linked. It is desirable to obtain analogues for directed graphs as well. Although Thomassen showed that the Bollobás-Thomason Theorem does not hold for general directed graphs, he proved an analogue of the theorem for tournaments-there is a function f(k) such that every strongly f(k)-connected tournament is k-linked. The bound on f(k) was reduced to O(k log k) by Kühn, Lapinskas, Osthus, and Patel, who also conjectured that a linear bound should hold. We prove this conjecture, by showing that every strongly 452k-connected tournament is k-linked.
